title: Ben Horowitz on Leadership and Culture

rawLines.text: okay so we we have your book in the
lobby The Hard Thing About Hard Things
it's sold a trillion copies multiple
reprints probably not a trillion but
yeah a lot um and you're an expert in
making tough decisions in business
helping others navigate those moments
that matter i would say Washington is
going through just an incredible moment
of transformation uh so I want to start
talking about leadership and you know we
have well let me first start with some
founders you know you had Alli up here
earlier today you have other founders in
your portfolio ariel from Navon uh who
was like a tank commander you have these
very very special founders so what what
is it about these founders that really
makes you believe that they were going
to create great companies
yeah so I think it comes back to like
the CEO job and like what is that and
you know why is it difficult and so the
way to think about it is okay you invent
something it's something the world may
want so now you start a company um you
hire every person you know that you
think is good or and kind of respect you
you know raise money from people you go
sign up customers the customers depend
on you to succeed there's a lot of
pressure but you don't actually know
what you're doing you've never been a
CEO you've never run a big organization
and so you get in you get yourself into
these situations where oh maybe that
executive isn't good enough or maybe
like the product architecture needs to
be reworked and so forth and you know
everybody's depending on you you're all
you do is work so you don't have any
life outside of this so your life is
basically over if this company fails and
you and you don't know that that's the
right thing to do um you only think it
and then you have people around you
telling you no it's not the right thing
to do so how do you kind of trust your
eyes trust what you think and go do it
it's a very difficult problem and that's
where basically I see CEOs fail all the
time is in that hesitation between okay
I see it but I can't act on it um
because there's just too much scary
stuff between me and that uh and the
advantage you have with Ali or Ariel is
they understand the value of urgency and
the danger of hesitation you heard Ali's
story like he hesitated you know like
one more hour like he's probably dead um
and he he lives his whole life with that
in his mind um and Ariel as a tank
commander also gets that so even though
they kind of had that same situation
same problem they got through the
hesitation problem faster because
they're like well look there's the cost
of action but the cost of inaction is so
intense that like I' I know I have to
make a move and so that's why those kind
of uh those backgrounds are at least
helpful in learning how to be a CEO and
do you think that and you know this from
your days as a CEO this is true uh do
you think that with all the people
coming into Washington who are not
traditional Washington insiders they're

to bring that kind of an approach or
they you think they're we're going to
have the brick wall experience where
they run into the bureaucracy because I

where we've had this many people that
are not career bureaucrats coming into
administrative roles presidential
appointed positions
yeah well it's interesting a lot of
people from our firm are are in
Washington now
you know I think that um you know
culture can change fast uh
and there's always anytime there's
change in any organization there the
antibodies come out and then the
question is like you know what force is
stronger is the force of the new
direction stronger or the antibodies
stronger and I think that you know
particularly in the case of the the
white house and the administration
because Trump was president before uh I
think their experience that time in
talking to Jared and and talking to uh
the
president was well we didn't go hard
enough you know we we kind of were too
differential to the system which is
probably a shock to a lot of people
because they're like they were
differential um but they they were in
term one much more than they are in term
two so I think that I think change is
going to happen at a pretty fast rate i
mean we'll see where it goes and you
know how positive the change is is still
TBD but um they're definitely going for
it absolutely we uh I know we I got to
be careful how I ask this question but I
think General Fenton's still listening
to what I'm saying so I do want to talk
about DoD and culture and change because
you are both a student of organizational
culture but you are also a teacher of
how to change culture and how to create
the culture that that you want and what
and what culture really is so you know
we know that the DoD now is trying to
really reassess what how do they set
themselves up for the next hundred years
what do they want culture to be how
would you advise the DoD to think about
changing their culture and how to think
about culture and what it really means
yeah so you know my favorite um kind of
definition of culture comes from the
samurai which is you know a culture is
not a set of beliefs it's a set of
actions and I think if you think of it
through that lens it's like okay what do
we do on a daily basis that kind of
constitutes the culture and how we
operate and how we think about things
and so forth and I think that um you
know the the the bad thing that's
happened to the culture in the DoD is
it's become kind
of you know politically or and
bureaucratically driven as opposed to
mission driven that's the complaint at
least that I hear all the time is wow we
used to be about winning now we're about
like everything else uh and to change
culture you know probably the best story
um of culture change that that I've that
I ever read about as I studied it was
the the story of the Haitian Revolution
where uh Tusant Lovaturure it was the
only successful slave revolt that
resulted in an independent state in the
history of humanity so like a very rare
event and the the reason it was so rare
um is that slave culture is not military
culture it's like it's the opposite in
that if you're a slave there's no
tomorrow you don't own tomorrow you
don't own anything so long-term planning
and kind of strategy and kind and trust
in
particular comes from that long-term
thinking right i'm going to do something
for you today David because I trust that
in a month from now you'll do something
for me well like what if there is no
month from now then there's no trust so
you have this low trust very kind of
difficult culture to build an army
against and so there were no successful
slave revolts
tell two cent how did he do it well he
changed he shocked the culture into a
new culture um and he did it in kind of
several ways and I just give you two
examples which I think are probably
relevant for the DoD is one is like let
me just make a rule that shows you
yesterday has nothing to do with today
and one of the rules that he made which
was and this is you know Haiti in the
1790s so it's raping and pillaging and
like a very kind of aggressive mercenary
type of warfare and he just made the
rule look officers in my army can't
cheat on their wives otherwise you're
dismissed no concubines no none of that
and everybody was completely shocked
because it's just so antithetical to the
culture that was running and his point
was look I have to be able to trust you
um and if if if your wife can't trust
you then like how am I going to trust
you and it was just a very simple
rule that indicated this is where we're
going trust is the most important thing
in the army and that's the one thing I'm
going to dismiss you on second thing he
did was he changed out a lot of the
leadership for the guys he captured so
he would capture uh kind of generals
from the French army from the Spanish

would put them in officer position so he
had he brought in the culture of the
enemy military uh to refine the thing
and I think that you know not
necessarily that we would bring in um a

like that but just bringing in uh
leadership from a different culture from
the culture you want and adopting that
into your own are kind of two mechanics
that I think uh at least historically
were very very effective and he ended up
building you know quite an astonishing
like if you look at kind the history of
